item.title: Connected components
item.description: Definition Let \(p\) be a point in a topological space \((X, \T)\). The component of \(p\) in \(X\) is the union of all connected subsets of \(X\) that contain \(p\). Properties Theorem 8.18: Given a space \(X\), every component in \(X\) is connected, closed, and not contained in any strictly larger connected set. Theorem 8.19: Given a space \(X\), the set of components of \(X\) is a partition of \(X\).

item.title: Connectedness
item.description: Definition A topological space \((X, \T)\) is connected if and only if \(X\) cannot be written as the disjoint union of two nonempty open sets. Properties Theorem 8.1 A space \(X\) being connected is equivalent to the following conditions: There does not exist a continuous function \(f: X \to \Rs\) such that \(f(X) = \{0,1\}\). \(X\) cannot be written as the disjoint union of two nonempty separated sets. \(X\) cannot be written as the disjoint union of two nonempty closed sets.

item.title: Continuity
item.description: Continuous functions can be drawn without picking up your pencil…? The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\), limit related definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if the limit of \(f\) at \(c\) exists and \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)\). That is, for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - c \vert < \delta\) implies \(\vert f(x) - f(c) \vert < \varepsilon\).

item.title: Cone over a topological space
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. Then the cone over \(X\) is the identification space \(X^*\) of the product \(X \times [0,1]\) where \[X^* = \{\{(x,t)\} \mid x \in X, t \in (0,1]\} \cup \{\{(x,0) \mid x \in X\}\}.\] Examples If \(X\) is a compact subset of \(\R^n\) with the standard topology, then the cone over \(X\) is homeomorphic to the space \(C\) constructed in the following way: view \(\R^n\) as a subset of \(\R^{n+1}\), let \(x_0 \in \R^{n+1} - \R^n\), and define \(C\) to be the union of all line segments from \(x_0\) to points \(x \in X\).

item.title: Normal spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is normal if and only if for every pair of disjoint, closed sets \(A\) and \(B\), there are disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(A \subset U\) and \(B \subset V\). Properties Theorem 4.9: A space \((X, \T)\) is normal if and only if for every closed set \(A \subset X\) and open set \(U\) containing \(A\), there exists an open set \(V\) such that \(A \subset V\) and \(\overline{V} \subset U\).

item.title: Quotient spaces
item.description: Generalizing identification spaces. Definitions Let \((X,\T)\) be a topological spaces, let \(Y\) be a set, and let \(f: X \to Y\) be a surjection. Define the quotient topology on \(Y\) to be the topology in which \(U \subset Y\) is open if and only if \(f\inv(U)\) is open in \(X\). Given a surjective map \(f: X \to Y\) between topological spaces \(X\) and \(Y\), we call \(f\) a quotient map and \(Y\) a quotient space if and only if the topology on \(Y\) is the quotient topology with respect to \(Y\).

item.title: Retractions
item.description: Definition Let \(A\) be a subset of a topological space \((X, \T)\). A continuous function \(r: X \to A\) is called a retraction and \(A\) is called a retract if and only if for all \(a \in A\), we have that \(r(a) = a\). Properties Theorem 7.64: Let \(X\) be a normal space and let \(A \subset X\) be closed and homeomorphic to \([0,1]\) as a subspace of \(\Rs\). Then there exists a retraction \(r: X \to A\).

item.title: Wedge sums
item.description: Gluing two spaces together at a point. Definition Let \(A\) and \(B\) be disjoint topological spaces with points \(p \in A\) and \(q \in B\). We define the wedge sum of \(A\) and \(B\) relative to the points \(p\) and \(q\), denoted \(A \vee B\) to be the quotient space \(A \cup B / p \sim q\). Examples The bouquet of \(n\) circles is the result of gluing together \(n\) circles at one point.

item.title: Identification spaces
item.description: Definitions Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(X^*\) be a partition of \(X\). The identification map \(f: X \to X^*\) is the surjective map that takes each point of \(X\) to the part of the partition \(X^*\) containing it. The identification space of \(X\) under the map \(f\) is the set \(X^*\) with a topology defined as follows: a set \(U \subset X^*\) is open in \(X^*\) if and only if the preimage \(f\inv(U)\) is open in \(X\).

item.title: The box topology
item.description: Another, weirder topology on an infinite product. Definition Let \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) be a (possibly infinite) collection of topological spaces. The box topology on the product \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) is the topology generated by a basis consisting of sets of the form \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} U_\alpha\) where \(U_\alpha\) is open in \((X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\) for each \(\alpha\). Properties As a consequence of Theorem 3.27, if the collection \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is finite, the box topology on \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) is the same as the product topology.

item.title: Homeomorphisms
item.description: Definition Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be topological spaces. A function \(f: X \to Y\) is called a homeomorphism if it is bijective and both \(f\) and \(f\inv\) are continuous. When there exists a homeomorphism \(f: X \to Y\), we say the two spaces \(X\) and \(Y\) are homeomorphic or that they are topologically equivalent. Properties Theorem 7.26: Being homeomorphic is an equivalence relation on topological spaces. Theorem 7.28: If \(f: X \to Y\) is a continuous bijection, then being open or closed is equivalent to being a homeomorphism.

item.title: The product topology
item.description: Definitely review the page on infinite cartesian products for this one. Definition Let \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) be a collection of topological spaces. We can define a topology on the product \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) generated by the subbasis consisting of sets of the form \(\pi_\beta\inv (U_\beta)\) where \(\pi_\beta\) is a projection function, \(\beta \in \lambda\), and \(U_\beta\) is open in the space \((X_\beta, \T_\beta)\). We call this topology the product topology.

item.title: Embeddings
item.description: Definition Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be topological spaces. A function \(f: X \to Y\) is an embedding if and only if the function \(f: X \to f(X)\) is a homeomorphism where \(f(X)\) has the relative topology from \(Y\). Properties Corollary 7.31: Let \(X\) be compact and \(Y\) be Hausdorff. Then if \(f: X \to Y\) is an injective and continuous map, it is an embedding.

item.title: Basis for a topological space
item.description: Similar to the ideas behind bases in other areas of math. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(\B \subset \T\). \(\B\) is a basis for the topology \(\T\) if and only if every open set is the union of elements of \(\B\). If \(\B\) is a basis, we call \(B \in \B\) a basic open set. Properties Theorem 3.1: A set \(\mathcal{B}\) is the basis for a given topology \(\mathcal{T}\) on a set \(X\) if and only if

item.title: Closed functions
item.description: Definition A function \(f: X \to Y\) for topological spaces \(X\) and \(Y\) is called closed if and only for every closed set \(A \subset X\), the image \(f(A)\) is closed in \(Y\). Properties Theorem 7.21: If \(X\) is normal and \(f: X \to Y\) is continuous, surjective, and closed, then \(Y\) is normal.

item.title: Open functions
item.description: Definition A function \(f: X \to Y\) for topological spaces \(X\) and \(Y\) is called open if and only for every open set \(U \subset X\), the image \(f(U)\) is open in \(Y\). Properties Theorem 7.22: If \(X\) has basis \(\{B_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) and \(f: X \to Y\) is continuous, surjective, and open, then \(Y\) has a basis \(\{f(B_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\). This also means that if \(X\) is 2st countable, then so is \(Y\).

item.title: $T_1$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is a \(T_1\)-space if and only if for every pair of distinct points \(x\) and \(y\), there exist open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(y \in V\) but \(x \notin V\) and \(y \notin U\). Properties Theorem 4.1: A space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_1\) if and only if singletons are closed. Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is Hausdorff, \(T_3\), or \(T_4\), it is also \(T_1\).

item.title: Countably compact spaces
item.description: Similar to being compact, but weaker… Definition A topological space \((X, \T)\) is countably compact if and only if every countable open cover has a finite subcover. Properties Theorem 6.25: If, in addition to being countably compact, a space \(X\) is Lindelöf, \(X\) is also compact. Theorem 6.26: If \(X\) is a \(T_1\) space, \(X\) is countably compact if and only if all infinite subsets of \(X\) have limit points.

item.title: Lindelöf spaces
item.description: Similar to being compact, but weaker… Definition A topological space \((X, \T)\) is Lindelöf if and only if every open cover has a countable subcover. Properties Theorem 6.25: If, in addition to being Lindelöf, a space \(X\) is countably compact, \(X\) is also compact. Theorem 6.27: All uncountable sets in a Lindelöf space have limit points.

item.title: Compactness
item.description: Definitions Let \((X,\T)\) be a topological space and with a subset \(A \subset X\). A collection \(\Cov = \{C_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is called a cover of \(A\) if and only if \(A \subset \bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} C_\alpha\). The collection \(\Cov\) is called an open cover if each \(C_\alpha\) is an open set. A collection \(\Cov'\) is a subcover of \(\Cov\) if it is a subset of \(\Cov\) and is also a cover of \(A\).

item.title: Definition of a topology
item.description: A topology on a set is a way of determining which subsets are open, closed, neither, or both. Elements of open sets can be thought of as being “close” in a way that isn’t dependent on notions of distance. If \(X\) is a set and \(\mathcal{T}\) is a topology on \(X\), then we call \((X, \mathcal{T})\) a topological space. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. Then \(\mathcal{T}\) is a topology on \(X\) if and only if \(\mathcal{T}\) is a collection of subsets of \(X\) such that:

item.title: First countable spaces
item.description: Definitions A topological space \((X, \T)\) is called 1st countable if and only if every point in \(X\) has a countable neighborhood basis. Properties Theorem 5.14: Every 2nd countable space is also 1st countable. Theorem 5.18: In a 1st countable space, any set \(A\) with a limit point \(p\) has a sequence of points in \(A\) that converges to \(p\). Theorem 5.19: Every 1st countable space is hereditarily 1st countable.

item.title: Second countable spaces
item.description: Definition A topological space \((X, \T)\) is called 2nd countable if and only if it has a countable basis. Properties Theorem 5.9: All 2nd countable spaces are separable. Theorem 5.11: All uncountable sets in a 2nd countable space have a limit point. Exercise 5.12: Every 2nd countable space is hereditarily 2nd countable . Exercise 5.13: If \(X\) and \(Y\) are 2nd countable spaces, then \(X \times Y\) is 2nd countable under the product topology.

item.title: Arithmetic progression topology
item.description: Definition The arithmetic progression topology is a topology on \(\mathbb{Z}\) generated by the basis of sets of arithmetic progressions (sets of the form \(\{az + b \mid z \in \mathbb{Z}\}\) for \(a,b \in \mathbb{Z}\), \(a \neq 0\)) and is denoted \(\mathbb{Z}_\text{arith}\). Properties Separation Properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Regular and a \(T_3\)-space Normal and a \(T_4\)-space Countability Properties Separable 2nd countable 1st countable

item.title: Countable complement topology
item.description: Basically what the name makes it sound like. It’s similar in definition to the finite complement topology. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. A set \(U\) is in the countable complement topology if and only if \(X - U\) is countable or if \(U = \emptyset\). This topology is also called the cocountable topology. Properties Countable sets are closed in this topology. For a countable set, the countable complement topology is just the discrete topology.

item.title: Finite complement topology
item.description: Basically what the name makes it sound like. Similar in definition to the countable complement topology. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. A set \(U\) is in the finite complement topology if and only if \(X - U\) is finite or if \(U = \emptyset\). This topology is also called the cofinite topology. Properties Finite sets are closed in the finite complement topology. For a finite set, the finite complement topology is just the discrete topology.

item.title: Indiscrete topology
item.description: The coarsest possible topology on a set \(X\). Definition Let \(X\) be a set. The indiscrete topology is \(\mathcal{T} = \{\emptyset, X\}\). The topological space \((X, \{\emptyset, X\})\) is called an indiscrete space. Properties By definition, the only sets in the indiscrete topology that are open are \(X\) and \(\emptyset\), and these are also the only closed sets. Separation Properties Not a \(T_1\)-space Not Hausdorff Regular but not a \(T_3\)-space Normal but not a \(T_4\)-space The indiscrete topology is regular and normal vacuously.

item.title: K-topology
item.description: Denoted \(\Rh\) in the textbook I’ve been using, the K-topology is a topology on \(\mathbb{R}\). Definition Let \(K = \{1/n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}\) be the harmonic sequence. The K-topology on \(\mathbb{R}\) is generated by the basis containing sets of the form \((a,b)\) and sets of the form \((a,b) - K\) where \(a, b \in \mathbb{R}\) with \(a < b\). Properties \(\Rh\) is finer than the standard topology. Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Not regular or \(T_3\) (can’t separate \(0\) and \(K\)) Not normal or \(T_4\) Countability Properties Separable 2nd countable 1st countable

item.title: The discrete topology
item.description: The discrete topology is the finest topology on a given set. A set together with the discrete topology is called a discrete space. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. Then the discrete topology on \(X\) contains all subsets of \(X\), that is, the topology is \(\mathcal{T} = 2^X\), the power set of \(X\). Properties If \((X, \mathcal{T})\) is a topological space, then it is a discrete space if and only if all singletons are open.

item.title: The Double Headed Snake
item.description: The body is the positive real line and the two heads are the points \(0'\) and \(0''\). Definition The Double Headed Snake is the topological space on the set \(\R_{+00}\) of all positive real numbers together with the numbers \(0'\) and \(0''\) that is generated by the basis \(\B\) containing sets of the form \((a,b)\), \((0,b) \cup \{0'\}\), and \((0,b) \cup \{0''\}\) where \(a,b \in \mathbb{R}\). Properties Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Not Hausdorff (can’t separate \(0'\) and \(0''\)) Not regular or a \(T_3\)-space Not normal or a \(T_4\)-space Countability Properties Separable 2nd countable 1st countable

item.title: The Sorgenfrey line
item.description: It’s like \(\R\) but finer and… worse. It’s a topological space also known as the lower limit topology on \(\R\), sometimes denoted \(\RLL\) or \(\mathbb{R}_{\text{bad}}^1\). Definition The Sorgenfrey Line is the topological space on \(\mathbb{R}\) generated by the basis of sets of the form \([a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x < b\}\) for \(a, b \in \mathbb{R}\). Properties Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Regular and a \(T_3\)-space Normal and a \(T_4\)-space Countability Properties Separable Not 2nd countable 1st countable

item.title: The standard topology
item.description: The standard topology is a topology defined on \(\mathbb{R}^n\) for \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). Definitions The Euclidean distance between two points \(x = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)\) and \(y = (y_1, y_2, \dots, y_n)\) is defined as \[d(x,y) = \left( \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2 \right)^{\frac{1}{2}}.\] An open ball of radius \(\varepsilon > 0\) around a point \(p \in \mathbb{R}^n\) is the set \(B(p, \varepsilon) = \{x \mid d(p,x) < \varepsilon\}\).

item.title: The sticky bubble topology
item.description: Definition Let \(\mathbb{H} = \{(x,y) \mid x,y \in \mathbb{R}, y \geq 0\}\). The upper half plane with the sticky bubble topology is this set (the upper half plane) with the topology generated by the basis containing all balls of the form \(B((x,y), r)\) where \(0<r \leq y\), and all balls of the form \(B((x,y),r) \cup \{(x,0)\}\) where \(r = y > 0\). Properties Separation properties \(T_1\)-space (since it’s Hausdorff) Hausdorff (since it’s \(T_3\)) Regular and a \(T_3\)-space (proof) Countability Properties Separable Not 2nd countable 1st countable

item.title: Neighborhood bases
item.description: Definition Let \(p\) be a point in a topological space \((X, \T)\). A collection of open sets \(\{U_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) in \(X\) is called a neighborhood basis for \(p\) if and only if \(p \in U_\alpha\) for all \(\alpha \in \lambda\), and for all open sets \(V\) with \(p \in V\), there exists a \(\beta \in \lambda\) such that \(p \in U_\beta \subset V\). Properties Theorem 5.15: If \(p\) is a point in a topological space with a countable neighborhood basis, then \(p\) also has a nested neighborhood basis.

item.title: Order topology
item.description: Definition Let \(X\) be a set totally ordered by a relation \(\leq\). The order topology on \(X\) is the topology generated by the basis \(\B\) where \(\B\) is the collection of subsets of \(X\) of the form \(\{x \in X \mid x < a\}\), \(\{x \in X \mid a < x\}\), or \(\{x \in X \mid a < x < b\}\) for \(a, b \in X\). Properties If \(X\) is a set totally ordered by a relation \(\leq\), then the order topology on \(X\) has a subbasis \(\Sub\) containing sets of the form \(\{x \in X \mid x < a\}\) or \(\{x \in X \mid a < x\}\).

item.title: The lexicographically ordered square
item.description: Sets have interesting closures. Definition The unit square \([0,1] \times [0,1]\) is totally ordered by the lexicographic order, and the lexicographically ordered square is the topological space formed from the unit square together with the associated order topology. Properties Many sets have very interesting, unexpected closures. See Exercise 3.21. Separation Properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Regular and a \(T_3\)-space These follow from the fact that this is a space with an order topology.

item.title: Completely normal spaces
item.description: Definitions Two sets \(A\) and \(B\) in a topological space are separated if and only if \(\overline{A} \cap B = \emptyset\) and \(A \cap \overline{B} = \emptyset\). A topological space \((X, \T)\) is completely normal if and only if for any two separated sets \(A\) and \(B\), there exist open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(A \subset U\) and \(B \subset A\). Properties Theorem 4.26: A topological space \((X, \T)\) is completely normal if and only if it is hereditarily normal.

item.title: Dense subsets
item.description: Definition A subset \(A \subset X\) in a topological space \((X, \T)\) is dense in \(X\) if and only if \(\overline{A} = X\), where \(\overline{A}\) is the closure of \(A\) in \((X, \T)\). Properties Exercise 5.1 A subset \(A \subset X\) is dense in \(X\) if and only if every open set in \((X, \T)\) contains a point in \(A\). Examples The rationals are dense in the reals with the standard topology \(\Rs\).

item.title: Fineness and coarseness
item.description: Given two topologies on a set \(X\), we can compare them with the notions of fineness and coarseness. You can think about the fineness of a topology determining the amount you can see (you “see” the open sets) when looking at the set \(X\). If a topology is very fine, you can see a lot of open sets, but if the topology is very coarse, things are “blurry” because there are few open sets.

item.title: Hausdorff spaces
item.description: Also called \(T_2\)-spaces. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is Hausdorff if and only if for every pair of distinct points \(x\) and \(y\), there exist disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(y \in V\). Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_3\), or \(T_4\), it is also Hausdorff and therefore also \(T_1\). Theorem 4.16:) The product of Hausdorff spaces is product, even for a possibly uncountable product.

item.title: Heredity
item.description: What properties do subspaces inherit? Definition Let \(P\) be a property of a topological space \((X, \T)\). Then the space is hereditarily \(P\) if and only if every subspace \(Y \subset X\) with the relative topology \(\T_Y\) also has the property \(P\). Properties Theorem 4.26: A topological space \((X, \T)\) is hereditarily normal if and only if it is completely normal. Examples Theorem 4.19: Hausdorff spaces are hereditarily Hausdorff. Theorem 4.

item.title: My topology self-study work
item.description: I’ve been using the book Topology Through Inquiry and proofs and exercises I’ve done from the book can be found here.

item.title: Regular spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is regular if and only if for every point \(x \in X\) and closed set \(A \subset X\) with \(x \notin A\), there exist disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(A \subset V\). Properties Theorem 4.8: A space \((X, \T)\) is regular if and only if for each point \(p \in X\) and open set \(U\) with \(p \in U\), there exists an open set \(V\) such that \(p \in V\) and \(\overline{V} \subset U\) (where \(\overline{V}\) is the closure of \(V\) in \((X, \T)\)).

item.title: Separable spaces
item.description: Defintion A topological space \((X, \T)\) is separable if and only if \(X\) has a countable dense subset. Properties Exercise 5.4: A space \((X, \T)\) being separable does not imply that all of its subspaces are separable. Theorem 5.5: If two spaces \(X\) and \(Y\) are separable, then \(X \times Y\) with the product topology is separable. Examples The space \(\Rs\) is separable, but \(\R\) with the discrete topology is not separable because the reals are uncountable and so for any countable subset, there is point not in the subset, and the set containing this point is open in the discrete topology, meaning not all open sets contain a point in the countable subset and so no countable subset can be dense.

item.title: Subbasis for a topological space
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(\Sub \subset \T\). \(\Sub\) is a subbasis for the topology \(\T\) if and only if the collection \(\B\) of all finite intersections of sets in \(\Sub\) is a basis for \(\T\). If \(\Sub\) is a subbasis, we call \(S \in \Sub\) a subbasic open set. Properties Exercise 3.13: If \(\B\) is a basis for a topology \(\T\), then it is also a subbasis.

item.title: Subspaces in topology
item.description: Much like in other areas, a subspace is a subset that still has extra structure. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(Y\) be a subset of \(X\). The collection \[\T_Y = \{ U \mid U = V \cap Y \text{ for some } V \in \T \}\] is a topology on \(Y\) called the subspace topology or the relative topology on \(Y\) inherited from \(X\). The space \((Y, \T_Y)\) is called a (topological) subspace of \((X, \T)\).

item.title: Sequences
item.description: They’re like lists but they’re infinitely long. Definitions For real numbers, a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}\), where the image of the number \(n\) under \(f\) is typically called \(a_n\). The sequence is written by listing its images: \(a_1, a_2, \dots\) or for short, \(\{a_n\}\). In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to X\), where the image of the number \(i\) under \(f\) is typically called \(x_i\).

item.title: The topologist's sine curve
item.description: A set in the standard topology on \(\mathbb{R}^2\). Definition In \((\mathbb{R}^2, \mathcal{T}_\text{std})\), the topologist’s sine curve is the set \[S = \left\{ \left( x, \sin \left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \right) \, \bigg \vert \, x \in (0,1) \right\}.\] Properties Every point in the set \(\{(0,y) \mid -1 \leq y \leq 1 \}\) is a limit point of the topologist’s sine curve. Since none of the above points are in \(S\), \(S\) is not closed.

item.title: $T_4$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_4\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and normal. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_4\), it is also normal, \(T_3\), regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: $T_5$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_5\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and completely normal. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_5\), it is also completely normal by definition, normal since disjoint closed sets are separated, \(T_3\), regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: Open sets
item.description: Definition In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), an open set \(U\) is a set with \(U \in \mathcal{T}\). Properties of open sets Theorem 2.3: A set \(U\) is open if and only if for each point \(p \in U\), there exists an open set \(U_p\) such that \(p \in U_p \subset U\). If \(\{U_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is a collection of open sets, then \(\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) is open, but \(\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) need not be open.

item.title: Closures
item.description: Taking a set and adding a few points to make it closed. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space with \(A \subset X\). The closure of \(A\) in \(X\), denoted \(\overline{A}\), Cl\((A)\), or Cl\(_X(A)\) is the set \(A\) together with all its limit points in \(X\). Properties Theorem 2.13: The closure of a set is closed, that is, for a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), we have that \(\overline{\overline{A}} = \overline{A}\).

item.title: A big table of spaces and properties
item.description: In spaces where the base set \(X\) is not given, \(X\) is assumed to be uncountably infinite, and in the row for the product topology on \(X \times Y\), it is assumed that both \(X\) and \(Y\) have the property of interest. The labels 2nd and 1st are abbreviations for the countability properties. item.title: $T_3$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_3\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and regular. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_4\), it is also \(T_3\), and therefore also regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: Boundaries of sets
item.description: Definition For a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), the boundary of \(A\), denoted \(\partial A\) or Bd\((A)\), is the intersection of the closures of \(A\) and its complement, that is, the set \(\partial A = \overline{X} \cap \overline{X - A}\). Properties Theorem 2.28: If \(A\) is a set in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), the interior of \(A\), the boundary of \(A\), and the interior of the complement of \(A\) are disjoint sets whose union is \(X\).

item.title: Interior of a set
item.description: Points in the set and not on the boundary. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space and let \(A\) be a subset of \(X\). The interior of \(A\), denoted \(A^\circ\) or Int\((A)\), is the largest open set contained entirely within \(A\), that is, the set \[A^\circ = \bigcup_{U \subset A, \, U \in \mathcal{T}} U.\] Properties Theorem 2.26: A point \(p\) is an interior point of a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\) if and only if there exists an open set \(U\) with \(p \in U \subset A\).

item.title: Limits
item.description: Intuitively, “\(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\)” means that the outputs of a function \(f\) approaches the value \(L\) as the inputs approach the value \(a\). The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\) definition of a limit (and variants) Let \(f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and let \(a,L \in \mathbb{R}\). \(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\) if and only if for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(0 < \vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(\vert f(x) - L \vert < \varepsilon\).

item.title: Closed sets
item.description: Definition In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a closed set \(A\) is a subset of \(X\) that is equal to its closure (\(\overline{A} = A\)). That is, \(A\) contains all its limit points. Properties of closed sets Theorem 2.14: A set \(A\) is closed if and only if its complement \(X - A\) is open. If \(\lbrace A_\alpha \rbrace_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is a collection of closed sets, then \(\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) is closed, but \(\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) need not be closed.

item.title: Isolated points
item.description: Definition Let \((X,\mathcal{T})\) be a topological space, \(A\) a subset of \(X\), and \(p \in A\) a point. We say \(p\) is an isolated point if it is not a limit point of \(A\). Properties If \(p\) is an isolated point of a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), then there exists an open set \(U\) such that \(U \cap A = \{p\}\). Examples In the topological space defined by \(X = \{a,b,c,d\}\) and \(\mathcal{T} = \{\emptyset, X, \{a\},\{a,b\}\}\), the point \(b\) is in the set \(A = \{b,c\}\), but is not a limit point of \(A\) since \(\{a,b\}\) is open but \((\{a,b\} - \{b\}) \cap A = \emptyset\).

item.title: Limit points
item.description: Generalizing more things from calculus – this time the idea of a point being “arbitrarily close” to a set. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space, let \(A \subset X\) be a subset, and let \(p \in X\) be a point. We say that \(p\) is a limit point of \(A\) if and only if for each open set \(U\) containing \(p\), \((U - \{p\}) \cap A \neq \emptyset\).

item.title: The Cantor set
item.description: Definition Define \(C_0\) to be the subset \(C_0 = [0,1]\) of \(\R\) with the standard topology. Define \(C_1\) to be \([0,1/3] \cup [2/3,1]\), that is, \(C_0\) with its middle third removed. Continue defining \(C_n\) be removing the middle thirds of each one of the disjoint closed intervals that make up \(C_{n-1}\). Then the Cantor set, denoted \(C\), is the intersection \[C = \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty C_n.\] Properties Exercise 7.42: The cantor set is homeomorphic to the product \(\prod_{n \in \N} \{0,1\}\) where each factor \(\{0,1\}\) has the discrete topology.
